This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

This Companr's system of submarine telegraph mbles is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.

Palestine-Syrla Line,

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 pm., for JAPPA (for Jerusalem), CAIPPA (for Nezareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus.) TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINE, coptinding in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus.)
Red Sea Line,

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Badan and Suakin direot returning from Buakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. & steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah Pedas continuing every other week to Saakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah bat call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.

L'Agence Generale d'Egypte a Alexandrie, Rue de la Porte Rosette No. 6, a l'honneur de prévenir sa Clientèle d'Egypte qu'elle vient de recevoir les échantillons et ca! alogues de la Saison d'Hiver qui sont délivrés.gratuitecent on onvovés sans frais par la poste à toote personne qni en fera la demande. Un très bel a38ortimeut de jupons, poignoirs, corsages, bonneterio, fichue, parapluies, parfumerie et article de Paris est également mis en vente por place.

Tous nos envois pour Alexindrie et le Caire sont expédiés franco de port, quel qu'on soit | le montant, à l'exception des articles lourds et encombrants qui ne sont expédiés franco quo jusqu'au port d'embarquement.
Toutes nos marchandises sont marquées et facturées aux mêmes prix qu'à Paris. Les N. droits de douane sont à ajouter aux prix irdiqnés.
CAPITALIST
wanted with £12,000 for Cigarette Factory, exporting approximately 12 millions of cigarettes a year. Yearly revenụe probably 20%, as per last balance.
Please address letters F. D. S. c/o Egyptian | Gazette offices.
CAPTIVE OFFICERS
RELEASED.
CHERIF OF WAZAN'S
GOOD OFFICES
PATHFINDER AT TANGIER.
TANGIER, October 21. HMS Pathfinder bas sailed for the Apgbara coast with the brother of Valiente. It is hoped that the captive officers will be 'speedily re-l dor
"speedly to: during the night of Ta leased.
TANGLER, October 22. The negotiations for the release of the
British officers are broken off owing to fresh demands of Valiente. H.M.S. Pathfinder has returned home from Tetuan with Valiente's brother.
(Later). H.M.8. Pathfinder has left for Tetaan, taking the Cherii of Wazan, who is exerting his influence to make Valiente exchange prisoners.
(Later). H.M.S. Pathfinder has returned with the British officers, who were released through the good offices of the Cherif of Wazan.
TANGIER, October 22.
The Pathfinder has arrived, bringing back the two officers who were captured. Havas
UNREST IN RUSSIA.
STRIKES AND DISTURBANCES.
Moscow, October 21.
The railway strike is paralysing traffic. The telegraph employés have joined the movement Yesterday not a single train arrived here. (R.)
ST. PETERSBURG, October 21.A strong agitation prevails among the students at the academies and religious seminaries of the principal cities.
Serious disturbances have taken place at Minsk, where the Cossacks invaded the syna. gogoes and the Jewish school. 120 people were injured, a hundred of them seriously: ( Havas)

ST. PETERSBURG, October 22. Railway strikes are spreading throughout Russia. Moscow is practically out off from the rest of the country. 'It is stated that the strikes are the result of political mancavres aiming at the eventual starving of this city!
Ravpris Teren in and Moscow.
Moscow, October 22. The situation is critical owing to the state of excessive excitement of the workmen.
ADMIRAL TOGO.
PUBLIC ENTRY INTO TOKIO.

Tokio, October 22: Admiral Togo made his public entry to day to report to the Emperor the return of the fleet from the war. He was met by the Ministers, Generals, Admirals, and Diplomatiata, votes. d accompanied by Admirals Dewa, Kataoka,amimura, and their state. He drove through institution, her sister have cheering crowds to the Palace, where the Emperor received his report and then warmly praised the services of the Admiral, officers and men.
FRANCE, GERMANY, AND ENGLAND
NOTABLE ARTICLE IN "TEMPS."
PARIS, October 21.

The "Temps," in a noteworthy article, says that in the event of a war between Great Britain and Germany the policy of France will be an armed neutrality so formidable that it will prevent any one from thinking of implicating her in quarrel in which she is not pot concerned.
(Reuter)
THE ROYAL TOUR.
RENOWN EN ROUTE TO PORT SAID.
GENOA, October 21. H.M.S. "Ranown," with the Prince and Princess of Wales on board, has left for Port Said
M. LOUBET'S VISIT TO SPAIN.
PARIS, October 22.
President Loubet and M. Rouvier have started for Madrid.
(Router)
Paris, October 22.
M. Loubet and M. Rouvier have left forSpain and Portogal.
PARIS MUNICIPALITY.
END OF LONDON VISIT.
LONDON, October 21. After a week's moat cordial festivities, the
members of the Paris Manicipality have started for home.
(Reuter)
SAD DEATH OF BRITISH NAVAL COMMANDER.
LONDON, October 21.
A piece of machinery tell on Commander Phillips, of H.M.S. Victorious, who was directing the salvage of the Assistance, killing him on the spot.
MIKADO HONORS BRITISH
Tokio, October 21.
The Mikado has conferred on Admiral Noal
the First Class of the Rising Sun. Other officers were also decorated,

LOCAL AND GENERAL
A POUNDLING. --A new-born child was found abandoned yesterday in Sisters-street ad taken to hospital.
SUEZ CANAL.--222 vessels passed through the Canal from the 6th to the 20th inet., th
does from which amounted to fra. 6,109,689.11
STRAY Dogs. - Stray and ownerless dog found in the Sayeda Zonab quarter of Cairo during the night of Tuesday, will be poisoned by the police.
Fire broke out yesterday afternoon in the house of Mr. Antoine Anagasto, at Ramleh. It was extinguished by means of a fire pump, the damage being estimated at £150.
SANITARY DEPARTMENT. --On the advice of the Director-General of the Sanitary Department, the Ministry of the Interior bag authorised M. Jean Cacaris, chemist, to practise Egypt.
KASR EL ANI HOSPITAL +Dr. A. H. Brehaut has been appointed resident medical officer at the Kasr el Aini Hospital at a salary of L.E. 20.833 m. per month, dating from the 17th inst.
ROYAL BERKS. -A detachment of the 2nd Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment, in
charge of two officers, will leave Sidi Gaber station for Caito, en route to Khartoum, by the 3.49 p.m. train on Wednesday next.

THE RAMADAN NEw Moon. -Several observers from the Cairo Gouvernorat will observe the rising of the new moon on Saturday next so as to be able to officially confirm the commencement of Ramadan on the following day.

BATHING IN THE NILE.-An British Army Order, issued on Saturday, states that "owing to the dangerous nature of thunder currents in theNile, all bathing in this river is prohibited except where locally published permit it."
EGYPTIAN TRUST AND INVESTMENT, LIMITED.

-We are informed that Mr. Pericles Glymnopoulos, of the advisory board of this company in Egypt, has arrived in Paris, and was expected in London on or about the 20th inst, to confer with the directors on the company's
Business
FREEMASONRY.-It will be a source of gratification to the many friends in Egypt. of the

late Mr. Frank Allchin to learn that at the recent elections for the Royal Masonic Institute made his public entry for Girls in London, his daughter, Florice Emperor the return of the Violet, was among the 29 successful candidates, having secured a very large number of votes. This is the second of Mr. Allchin's daughters to be admitted to this excellent institution, her sister having entered a couple of years ago.

NILE TRIPS FOR RESIDENTS.-- As is usual at the commencement of the winter reason, for the first two or three sailings of their Nile steamers to Assouan, Messrs. Thos. Cook & Son, Limited, make a special reduction for residents of this country. The rates they are putting into operation for this season are £25, instead of £50, for the tourist service by the sailings to Assouan ex Cairo November 14, 29, and December 5, and £15, instead of £22, for the express service, by the siblings ex Cairo November 3, 10, 17, 24, and December 4 and 8. The journey to Assouan and back by tourist steamer takes 20 days, and the fare (which includes sight-seeing, etc.) is first-rate in every respect; the express steamers occupy 19 days, four days of which are spent at the hotel at Assouan, and three days at Luxor. Doubtless with the exceptionally hot summer which residents have experienced this year, many Government officials and others will be glad to avail themselves of one of these sailings.

THE COMING SEASON.
DISTINGUISHED VISITORS..
Prince Leopold of Battenburg is coming to Egypt for the benefit of his health, and will leave England in the S.S. Ormuz on November 18.
Lord and Lady Carton are likely to pay Lord Cromer a short visit in Cairo on their way to England next month.
The Dowager Countess of Donoughmore and Lady Norab Hely-Hutobinson are to winter in Egypt. They have arrived in London en route.
NO MORE PLAGUE

Egypt is how free from bubonic plague, and the weekly bulletin issued by the Sanitary Department states that no case was reported during last week. Three cases, however, remained under treatment after the issue of the previous bulletin, but of these two have recovered, and one has ended fatally. All these three casos occurred at Alexandria.
In view of the present freedom of the country from plague no-farther official bulletins will be issued unless a new case should be notified.
THE KHEDIVE.
H.H. the Khedive will spend to-day at Montazah Palace and will come to Ras-el-Tin at an early hour to-morrow morning for his farewell reception before leaving for Cairo.
EGYPTIAN ARMY

Leave of absence has been granted to El Bimbashi Wilson, 13th Sudanese, until December 31, and to Bl-Bimbashi Ruggel, Sudan Government Railways, until December 7. El Bimbashi Airoey, Inspector of the Babr el numbered, the bandred Drug Ghazal province, will resume duty to morrow. after two days' fighting, losis

We regret to learn that on account of ill health it has been found necessary to grant El Kaimakam Sorel-Cameron Bey, president of lof Sheiku Selim el Atrash and the Bahr el Ghazal Recruiting Commission, Nasr both only seventeen ye extension of gave until the 28th January next .

Among those who have returned from Bedogios,when Naz'ın Pasha, V. leiro end have resumed their duties under the intervened, and the Drases, Ezyptisn Arms we notice El Miralai Bond toward this excellent gover Bey, D S.O., Director of Steamers and Boats; El friendly, agreed to submit Miralei Matthews Boy, Governor of the him for settlement. Upper Nile province, El Bimbaahi Hodgson, Inspector of the Dongola province.
AMERICAN MISSION IN FAYOUM.
(From our CORRESPONDENT).

Medinet al-Fayoum, Saturday Mr. and Mrs. Reid and Mr. Boyd of the American Mission, have returned from holiday in the U.S.A. The work of the mission continues to have an excellent got, and the mission schools are thronged with children from the district. I vited the Medinet el Fayoum girls' school the other day and was (August 16. 1892) and was very kindly shown over the school by Miss Martin, the head-mistress, who has met with great success in teaching the girls, of every nationality, who attend the school.
EGYPTIAN LAND AND GENERAL TRUST
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,- In the "Bourse Egyptienne" of the 19th nst., repeated in the "Phare d'Alexandrie" of the 20th inet., under the heading "Bulletin de la Boarse," a movement is said to be advocated by a Cairo firm of brokers and a certain number of local shareholders of the above company, with a view to eappross the London board of adıninistration, and to substitute an Egyptian board of directors to take over the entire management of the affairs of the company, on the supposed grounds of continued friction between the present London and Cairo boards . I beg to state that this agitation against the Chairman and London board of directora does not emanate from the local board, as sach, whose sole members are Mr. Loosdorfer, Mr. Hooker (ex-managing director), and myself. My colleague, Mr. Lonsdorfer, has been absent in Barope since the early days of September, and does not return to Egypt till the 7th November, whilst I personally am al on the strong supporter of the London board in all their actions.--Yours faithfully,
H. CROOKSHANK PASHA,
Cairo, October 21.

p.hi: A special service was held at St Mark's Church, Alexandria, yesterday, and a trophy and inscription, simple and in excellent taste,
designed by Rear-Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, were erected for the occasion. It consisted

of the famous signal Eagland expects, etc.," below which which came the great admiral's dying words, "For God and my country," and the name Horatio Nelson in white letters on red. In the porch was hang a notice on which
appeared Nelson's portrait and an exact
reproduction in the international code colors
of his Trafalgar signal, with an appeal from free from the Nelson Centenary
Memorial Fand appended. Special hymns were
sung for the occasion, and the Rev. R.
Wormell adapted appropriate words to Sir Arthur Sullivan's well-known Jabilee hymn
Oh, King of Kings, whose reign of old.' one has ended fatally. All these rred at Alexandria.
A letter which has reached us from Syria shows that the stories of a general conflict be
tween Bedouins and Droses in the Hauran have
been much exaggerated. It appears that a Druse
caravan, while returning to the Hauran from
Damascus some six weeks ago, was attacked by a gang of Bedouins, and lost two men and most of its camela. On the news reaching the Hagran 300 Drase cavaliers decided to
make reprisale. Riding some days over desolate country in the east of the Hauran, they s
urprised the oftending tribe and took 700 camels. Two hundred of the raiders returned
with their spoil, the remainder, unsatisfied with their booty, rode on and captured some cattle, only to find themselves face to face with
an overwhelming force of Bedouing who had gathered to repel the attack. Heavily out numbered, the Hundred Druses bad to retire after two days' fighting, losing twenty men and as many horses.
Among the fallen notables were the sors
of of Sheiku Selim el Atrash and of Sheikh Said Nasr both only seventeen years of age. Five Bedonin lenders were killed. The whole force
of the Hanran Dow prepared to attack the Bedonios, when Naz'ın Pasha, Vali of Damakous, intervened, and the Druses, whosa feelings
toward this excellent governor are most friendly, agreed to submit the dispute to him for settlement.
The sad news comes from Constantinople of
the the death of Mr. William Shortland Richards H.B.M.'8 Conaal at Damasous. Mr. Richards appointed student interpreter in 1877 became vice-consul at Mosal in 18-3 and at

Bourgas in 1885. He was then promoted to be Consul for the E. Coast of the Red Sea (August 16, 1892) and was attacked and severely wounded by Bedouins in May, 1895 receiving compensation from the Turkish Go
vernment. In 1896 he was transferred to
Damascus. An excellent linguist, firm and
energetic console, always willing to give information and advira M. Richards won
formation and advice, Mr. Richards won the
respect of all who knew him. The writer has a

very pleasant recollection of the helpful kindness shown him by Mr. Richards, who was then in very poor health, at Damascus this year, while the firmness he showed when called to Beyroat, in the absence on leave of the Consul-General, during the last disturbances
, will long be remembered by the peaceable inhabitants--and by Rashid Bay.

Accompanied by the civil and military members of his household, HE. Ghazi Ahmed Mokhtar Pasha, Imperial Ottoman High Commissioner, leaves Hadra on Taekday next by special train leaving at 9 20 a.m. and arriving at Cairo station at 12.35 p.m.

div.p: A dinner party was given yesterday by Col. Utaonomiya, of the Japanese General Staff, before leaving for Tokio, on the terrace of the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo. Among the co lonel's guests were Major-General Sir F. R. Wingate Pa hs, Brig-General Ballook, General Sir R. von Slatin Pasha, Lient. Col. Lord E . Cecil, Col. Bernard Bey, Col. Matchell, Col. Hunter, Major Kenney Herbert, Major LStack, Major Davidson, Mr. Bonham Carter, Mr. Bonus, Capt. H. Lewin, Capt. R. Oven, and Capt. R. Collins.

p.hi: Lews Tharneyssen Pashs, A.D.C. to H.H.
the Khedive, and Tito Hakekian Pashs were
among the large number of well-known residents who returned from Europe to-day by
the Austrian packet, and whose names will la found in another column.
Sir Horace Pinching, Director-General of the Sanitary Department, has returned from leave.
Little Miss Victoria Wiogato, daughter of H.B. the Governor-General of the Sadan, Was
among the passengers who arrived from Eng
land by the new Moss liner to-day.
We regret to announce the death of Mah
mood Effendi Kamel, sanitary inspector the Tahta distriot, Ghirgeh province, which took place on the 18th inst.

div.p: CONSTANTINOPLE NOTES.
( FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT. )
. Constantinople, October 17.

M. Gryparis, Hellenio Minister at Constan tinople, has left such a pleasant memory in Egypt, that news of his forthcoming marriage with Mlle Ralli will be read with pleasure.he marriage takes place at Athens, and numerous well-known Greek residenta of Constantinople and the Greek Consul-General for Adrianople have already left for the Hellenic Capital. The "best mon" will be M. Rallys, president of the Council of Ministers, and M. Pesmazoglu, director-general of the Bank of Athens. Great preparations are being made at the Greek Legation here for the arrival of M. and Mme Gryparis, who only intend to make a short stay in Paris before returning to Constantinople. Some great receptions are expected at the legation this winter.
HE NEW EMIR OF MECCA.

Sherif Aly Paaha has just been appointed Emir of Mecoa. The new Emir is nophew of the llate Aan-el-Rafik, his predecessor in the post Sherif Aly has sent a message of loyalty and thanks to the Sultan. Meantime the sacred caravan has left for Mecca and Medins with the usual accompaniment of festivities and religious ceremonies. Husni Bey is in charge of the caravan and escort.
MARRIAGE.
KUDSI-JUREIDINI.
We may add that an exo The marriage of Elias Ef. Kudai, Alexandria correspondent of our contemporary "Al

Mokattam," with Miss Anissah Jureidini took place yesterday afternoon at the Orthodox church of Saidat El Nijah. After the ceremony the bride and bridegroom received the congratulations of their friends at their new house it Bolkeley, Ramleb. It was a very pleasant evening to Mc. Kadsi's numerous friends. The wedding presents, which were tastefal and numerous, were shown in a special room. An excellent supper crowool the evening. Among those present were the three well-known poets, Ahmed Efendi Nessim, Shaikh Shaheem Bl khezea, and Abbus Eff. Ma fi; the latter extemporised some veraog wbich were much appreciated. Ahmed Effendi Nessim, who accompanied Shahee . Bey Macarius from Cairo to attend the ceremony, then resd a long and pretty poem, which he had composed, and drank to the health of the Rev. Archimandrite Ilia, who was prosent.
STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
The new Mosa liner Monepthah arrived this morning from Liverpool, via Gibraltar, Algiers, and Malta, with passengers, mails, and general ourgo.
"The M.M. steamer Senegal, from Marseilles,passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday and is due here to-morrow morning.
CHRONIQUE THEATRALE
Salvini au Zizioia

Les représentations de Kean et Morte Civile ont attiré ane assistance choisie et plus nom-certainly was no fault of the go brouse que d'ordinaire. Le chef d'ævre d'A. a été en particulier bien joué par cette b fore, and again Port Said atta troupe composée d'éléments d'élite qui forment. Neithe un ensemble remarquable.

G. Salvini dans les rôles de Kean et de Corrado s'est distingaé surtout par l'originalité de son interprétation. Qu'il nous soit permis de dire à ce propos que Novelli e: Salvini play was not of a scientifi) o. different complètement dans leur manière d'in-Ingram, Jary and Williams w terpréter les grands auteurs comiques et tra giques et que les défauts de l'an mettent en. relief les qualités de l'autre.
Mme Ida Salvini a donné dans la Morte Civile, la juste mesure de son Disz dans le rolo do Dr Palmieri et C. Aureli fal dans coloi de Monseigneur ont contribué tors. Boulsot au succès de cette pièce.

Parmi l'assistance on remarquait quelques américaine de passage qui avaient tenus à Boulao r tə revoir Salvini dont le nom est, comme l'on Issit, fort populaire aux Etats-Unis depuis une Bany' batnjoyable game, by 10 quarantaine d'années.
Gardet a l'Alhambra

L'excellente troupe française Louis Cardet ten que nous avons eu l'occasion d'applaudir l'apnée passée à l'Alhambra débutera a ce! théâtre le 2 novembre prochain, à son retourBoulao. do Cairo.
